info: In German, states and conditions are expressed similarly to English but with some key differences. For weather, impersonal constructions with "es" are common, e.g., Es ist heiß ("It is hot") or Es regnet ("It is raining"). Personal states like hunger and thirst use "haben" (to have), e.g., Ich habe Hunger ("I am hungry," literally "I have hunger"). Temporary feelings and conditions often use "sein" (to be), e.g., Ich bin müde ("I am tired"). This structure often parallels English but employs idiomatic expressions and specific verbs depending on the context.

Temporary feelings and conditions often use "sein" (to be), e.g., Ich bin müde ("I am tired"). This structure often parallels English but employs idiomatic expressions and specific verbs depending on the context.

Personal states like hunger and thirst use "haben" (to have), e.g., Ich habe Hunger ("I am hungry," literally "I have hunger"). Temporary feelings and conditions often use "sein" (to be), e.g., Ich bin müde ("I am tired"). This structure often parallels English but employs idiomatic expressions and specific verbs depending on the context.
